title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ecclesiastes chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ecclesiastes Chapter 2.

questions.question: What did the author decide to prove with mirth in his heart?
questions.correctAnswer: Pleasure
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:1 states the author said in his heart he would prove with mirth and enjoy pleasure.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2:4, what did the author build for himself?
questions.correctAnswer: Houses
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:4 says the author made great works and built houses for himself.

questions.question: What did the author plant in his gardens and orchards?
options: Trees of all kinds of fruits
questions.correctAnswer: Trees of all kinds of fruits
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:5 describes the planting of trees of all kinds of fruits in gardens and orchards.

questions.question: What did the author get to water the trees he planted?
questions.correctAnswer: Pools of water
questions.explanation: According to Ecclesiastes 2:6, the author made pools of water to water the wood that bringeth forth trees.

questions.question: Who did the author say he had born in his house as servants?
questions.correctAnswer: Servants
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:7 mentions servants born in the author's house.

questions.question: What kinds of singers did the author gather for himself?
questions.correctAnswer: Men and women singers
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:8 states the author gathered men singers and women singers.

questions.question: What did the author say remained with him despite his greatness?
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:9 says the author's wisdom remained with him.

questions.question: What was the author's conclusion after looking at all his works?
options: All was vanity and vexation of spirit
questions.correctAnswer: All was vanity and vexation of spirit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:11 states that all the works the author had done were vanity and vexation of spirit.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2:13, what excelleth folly?
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:13 says that wisdom excelleth folly as far as light excelleth darkness.

questions.question: What did the author perceive about the fate of the wise and the fool?
options: One event happeneth to them all
questions.correctAnswer: One event happeneth to them all
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:14 states that one event happeneth to both wise and fool.

questions.question: True or False: The author said there is remembrance of the wise more than the fool forever.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:16 says there is no remembrance of the wise more than the fool forever.

questions.question: True or False: The author hated life because the work under the sun was grievous to him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:17 states the author hated life because the work wrought under the sun was grievous.

questions.question: True or False: The author said it was good to leave his labour to the next man without question.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:19 describes it as vanity that the man who comes after may rule over his labour, expressing doubt and despair about this.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ecclesiastes 2:24: 'There is nothing better for a man, than that he should ______ and drink, and that he should make his soul enjoy good in his labour.'
questions.correctAnswer: eat
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:24 states that there is nothing better than to eat and drink and enjoy good in labour.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2:26, what does God give to a man that is good in His sight?
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom, knowledge, and joy
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:26 says God gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy to a man that is good in His sight.

medium.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ecclesiastes Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling empty despite pursuing many pleasures and accomplishments. Based on Ecclesiastes 2, what biblical truth would you share about the pursuit of pleasure?
options: Pursuing pleasure alone leads to vanity and emptiness
Pleasure is the ultimate goal of life
Avoid all enjoyment to be truly wise
questions.correctAnswer: Pursuing pleasure alone leads to vanity and emptiness
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:1-3 and 2:11 show that seeking pleasure and accomplishments without God is vanity and vexation of spirit, meaning it ultimately leaves one empty.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 2 teach us about humility and contentment in regard to work and possessions?
options: All labor and possessions are ultimately vanity without God's blessing
One should strive to have more than others to be content
Work is unnecessary if one has riches
questions.correctAnswer: All labor and possessions are ultimately vanity without God's blessing
questions.explanation: Verses 2:18-20 explain that labor and possessions left to others is vanity; one must recognize God's sovereignty and be humble about earthly achievements.

questions.question: A friend is discouraged because their hard work seems to benefit others who may be unwise. What biblical principle from Ecclesiastes 2 can encourage them?
options: God's gifts and favor are the true source of joy beyond human labor
Hard work always results in immediate reward
One must control who inherits their labor to avoid loss
It is pointless to work if others benefit
questions.correctAnswer: God's gifts and favor are the true source of joy beyond human labor
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:21-26 teaches that despite human effort, enjoyment and wisdom come from God’s hand, reminding believers to trust Him rather than only human effort.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 2 reveal about the value of wisdom compared to folly?
options: Wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness
Folly is better because it leads to freedom
Wisdom and folly are equally valuable
Folly brings more joy than wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness
questions.explanation: Verse 2:13 clearly states that wisdom is superior to folly, just as light is better than darkness, teaching the virtue of seeking wisdom.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 2 counsel believers to respond to the reality that both wise and foolish people share the same fate?
options: Recognize life’s vanity but still pursue godly living with humility
Ignore the foolish and focus on worldly success
Avoid wisdom since it has no lasting benefit
Live recklessly because all end the same
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize life’s vanity but still pursue godly living with humility
questions.explanation: Verses 2:14-16 show that both wise and foolish die alike, highlighting humility and the importance of godly perspective despite life’s brevity.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2, what is a healthy attitude toward enjoyment of one’s work and life?
options: Enjoying labor and good things is a gift from God
Work should be endured without joy
Pleasure is sinful and to be avoided
One should always seek more and never rest
questions.correctAnswer: Enjoying labor and good things is a gift from God
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:24 and 2:26 affirm that eating, drinking, and enjoying labor are blessings from God, encouraging gratitude and contentment.

questions.question: A believer is overwhelmed with the vanity of life’s toil. What does Ecclesiastes 2 suggest about trusting God’s sovereignty in work?
options: Trust that God gives joy and wisdom beyond human effort
Stop working because all is vanity
Ignore God and rely on human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God gives joy and wisdom beyond human effort
questions.explanation: Verse 2:26 teaches that God grants wisdom and joy to those He favors, so trusting Him is essential when human toil seems vain.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 2 states that laughter and mirth are ultimately meaningless and mad.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:2 states that laughter is mad and mirth questions what it accomplishes, emphasizing their limitations without God.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 2 encourages believers to withhold joy from their hearts in their labor.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:10 says the author withheld not his heart from joy in his labor, teaching that rejoicing in work is appropriate.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ecclesiastes 2, there is nothing better for a man than that he should _____, and that he should make his soul enjoy good in his labour.
questions.correctAnswer: eat and drink
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:24 teaches that enjoying food and drink and taking pleasure in labor is the best gift from God.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 2 instruct us about the danger of placing ultimate trust in possessions and achievements?
options: They will be left to others and are ultimately vanity
They are the true measure of a person’s worth
questions.correctAnswer: They will be left to others and are ultimately vanity
questions.explanation: Verses 2:18-19 warn that possessions and achievements left to others do not bring lasting value, reminding us to trust God.

questions.question: A believer struggles with envy over another’s success. What perspective does Ecclesiastes 2 offer on human work and success?
options: Success and work are vanity without God’s blessing and ultimate purpose
Human work is the only thing that matters
Envy is justified when others succeed
questions.correctAnswer: Success and work are vanity without God’s blessing and ultimate purpose
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:11 and 2:17 show that all human achievements are vanity and vexation of spirit without recognizing God’s sovereignty.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 2 teach about the relationship between wisdom, knowledge, and equity in labor?
options: Labor in wisdom, knowledge, and equity may still be left to others, showing human limitations
Labor without wisdom is always rewarded
Knowledge guarantees success and lasting legacy
questions.correctAnswer: Labor in wisdom, knowledge, and equity may still be left to others, showing human limitations
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:21 reveals that even wise labor may be inherited by others regardless of their character, teaching humility and trust in God.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 2 advise believers dealing with despair over life’s apparent futility?
options: Recognize that joy and wisdom come from God’s hand despite vanity
Give up all effort and hope
Ignore spiritual truths and live for self
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that joy and wisdom come from God’s hand despite vanity
questions.explanation: Verses 2:24-26 emphasize that God provides joy and wisdom, encouraging believers to trust Him even when life feels vain.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2, what is the result of giving oneself fully to wine and folly in search of meaning?
options: It leads to recognizing vanity and lack of lasting profit
It brings true and lasting happiness
It is the way to gain wisdom
It ensures success under the sun
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to recognizing vanity and lack of lasting profit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:3 and 2:11 describe seeking meaning through folly and wine only to find all is vanity and vexation of spirit.

hard.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ecclesiastes Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 2, the author describes pursuing various pleasures and works. What conclusion does he repeatedly reach about these pursuits?
options: They are ultimately vanity and vexation of spirit
They are the path to wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: They are ultimately vanity and vexation of spirit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:1 and 2:11 both highlight that despite all efforts in pleasure and work, the author finds these pursuits to be vanity and vexation of spirit.

questions.question: How does the author of Ecclesiastes 2 compare wisdom and folly?
options: Wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness
Wisdom and folly are equally meaningless
Folly brings more joy than wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:13 explicitly states that wisdom excels folly as far as light excels darkness, emphasizing the superiority of wisdom.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2, what is the fate of both the wise and the fool after death?
options: Both die and are forgotten; no remembrance remains
The wise are remembered forever, the fool is not
The fool is punished eternally, the wise rewarded
Only the wise receive eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: Both die and are forgotten; no remembrance remains
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:16 teaches that both wise and fool die alike and that there is no lasting remembrance of the wise over the fool.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Ecclesiastes 2:1-11 to emphasize the futility of human endeavors?
options: Chiasm, to mirror the cycles of pleasure and despair
Parable, to teach a moral lesson
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, to mirror the cycles of pleasure and despair
questions.explanation: The structure of Ecclesiastes 2:1-11 is chiastic, reflecting the author’s journey from pursuing pleasure to recognizing its vanity, and returning to despair, underscoring the cyclical futility.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew word 'hebel' (vanity) used throughout Ecclesiastes 2 signify in its broader biblical context?
options: Breath or vapor, indicating transient and futile nature
questions.correctAnswer: Breath or vapor, indicating transient and futile nature
questions.explanation: The term 'hebel' in Ecclesiastes 2:1 and elsewhere connotes something fleeting like breath or vapor, symbolizing the temporary and ultimately meaningless nature of worldly pursuits.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 2:3 mentions the author seeking to 'acquaint mine heart with wisdom' while indulging in wine. What cultural significance does this reflect from the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: The tension between indulgence and the pursuit of wisdom in royal courts
The prohibition of alcohol consumption in Israelite law
The exclusive use of wine in religious rituals
The rejection of wisdom as folly
questions.correctAnswer: The tension between indulgence and the pursuit of wisdom in royal courts
questions.explanation: The verse reflects the ancient Near Eastern royal practice of balancing pleasure with wisdom, as kings often indulged in wine but also sought wisdom to rule effectively.

questions.question: What is the significance of the author’s accumulation of servants, singers, silver, and gold in Ecclesiastes 2:7-8?
options: Demonstrates the worldly wealth and power yet ultimately meaningless
Shows divine blessing and eternal reward
questions.correctAnswer: Demonstrates the worldly wealth and power yet ultimately meaningless
questions.explanation: The passage shows the author’s great earthly wealth and pleasures, which he later concludes to be vanity and without lasting profit (Ecclesiastes 2:11).

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the theme of Ecclesiastes 2:11 about the vanity of human labor under the sun?
options: 1 Corinthians 15:58 – The labor is not in vain in the Lord
James 2:14 – Faith without works is dead
Philippians 3:8 – Counting all as loss for Christ
Hebrews 11:6 – Without faith it is impossible to please God
questions.correctAnswer: 1 Corinthians 15:58 – The labor is not in vain in the Lord
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:58 contrasts earthly vanity with eternal purpose, echoing Ecclesiastes 2:11’s theme that labor under the sun alone is vanity.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 2:14 contrasts the wise and the fool using the imagery of light and darkness. How does this parallel other biblical imagery?
options: It parallels John 1:5 where light overcomes darkness
It parallels Leviticus laws on purity
It parallels Psalms on the wicked’s destruction
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels John 1:5 where light overcomes darkness
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Ecclesiastes 2:14 of wisdom as light and folly as darkness aligns with John 1:5’s imagery of light overcoming darkness, symbolizing knowledge and truth prevailing over ignorance.

questions.question: What is the author's attitude toward life and labor as expressed in Ecclesiastes 2:17-18?
options: He hates life and his labor because it will be inherited by others
He rejoices in his labor and sees it as eternal
He is indifferent to labor and life
He fears labor and avoids it
questions.correctAnswer: He hates life and his labor because it will be inherited by others
questions.explanation: Verses 17-18 reveal the author's despair and hatred toward life and labor, especially because the fruits of his work will be left to others, underscoring the futility theme.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 2:24-25, what does the author suggest is the best enjoyment for a man under the sun?
options: To eat, drink, and enjoy good in his labor given by God
questions.correctAnswer: To eat, drink, and enjoy good in his labor given by God
questions.explanation: The author acknowledges in verses 24-25 that the best thing is to enjoy life’s simple pleasures and labor as a gift from God, providing a theological grounding for joy.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 2:26 contrasts God’s gifts to the good man and the sinner. What theological theme does this highlight?
options: Divine justice and providence where wisdom and joy are gifts to the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Divine justice and providence where wisdom and joy are gifts to the righteous
questions.explanation: Verse 26 emphasizes that God gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy to those who are good in His sight, while the sinner experiences toil, highlighting divine justice and providence.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 2 teaches that laughter and mirth are ultimately meaningful and fulfilling in life.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:2 explicitly states that the author considered laughter mad and questioned what mirth accomplishes, indicating their ultimate futility.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 2:12 suggest about the actions of those who come after a king?
options: They do nothing new but repeat what has been done
They innovate new laws and traditions
They bring wisdom that surpasses the past
questions.correctAnswer: They do nothing new but repeat what has been done
questions.explanation: Verse 12 reflects the theme of cyclical history and futility, noting that those who follow do what has already been done, emphasizing repetition and vanity.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 2:23 speaks about the heart not taking rest in the night. What does this reveal about the human condition according to the author?
options: Life is filled with sorrow and unrest despite labor
Humans find peace in their work
Night is a time of joy and restfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Life is filled with sorrow and unrest despite labor
questions.explanation: The verse describes ongoing sorrow and grief, indicating that human toil does not bring lasting peace or rest, illustrating the existential struggle.

theological.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ecclesiastes Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2, what conclusion does the Preacher reach about pleasure and mirth?
options: It is the ultimate purpose of life
It is a sign of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: It is vanity
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:1 states that the Preacher tried mirth and pleasure and found them to be vanity. This echoes Ecclesiastes 1:2 and aligns with the New Testament teaching that earthly pleasures are temporary (1 John 2:17; Matthew 6:19-21; James 4:3).

questions.question: What does the Preacher say about laughter and mirth in Ecclesiastes 2?
options: Laughter is mad and mirth does not accomplish anything
Laughter is wise and mirth brings joy
Laughter is a gift from God and mirth is eternal
Laughter and mirth are signs of true faith
questions.correctAnswer: Laughter is mad and mirth does not accomplish anything
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:2 describes laughter as mad and questions the value of mirth. This sober view reflects the transient nature of human joy apart from God (Psalm 39:5; Proverbs 14:13; Ecclesiastes 7:3; Luke 6:21).

questions.question: Which of the following did the Preacher NOT do to seek satisfaction according to Ecclesiastes 2?
questions.correctAnswer: Perform miracles
questions.explanation: The Preacher describes building houses, planting vineyards, and gathering singers (Ecclesiastes 2:4-8), but there is no mention of performing miracles. His pursuits were worldly and human-centered, highlighting the limits of human effort apart from divine intervention (John 6:26; Jeremiah 9:23-24).

questions.question: What does the Preacher say about the wisdom he possessed in relation to his great works?
options: His wisdom was greater than his works
questions.correctAnswer: His wisdom remained with him
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:9 indicates that despite his great works and possessions, his wisdom remained. This shows an awareness of the value of wisdom, paralleling Proverbs 3:13-18, James 1:5, and the teaching that wisdom is a gift from God (Colossians 2:3).

questions.question: What is the Preacher's final verdict on all his labor and accomplishments under the sun?
options: It was vanity and vexation of spirit
It was the foundation for true happiness
questions.correctAnswer: It was vanity and vexation of spirit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:11 concludes that all his works and labor were vanity and vexation of spirit, emphasizing the futility of life without God, consistent with Ecclesiastes 1:14, Romans 8:20-22, and Hebrews 9:27.

questions.question: How does the Preacher compare wisdom and folly in Ecclesiastes 2?
options: Wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness
Folly excels wisdom as darkness excels light
Wisdom and folly are equally vain
Wisdom is foolishness and folly is wise
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:13 affirms that wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness, which aligns with Proverbs 1:7, James 3:17, and John 1:4-5, highlighting the value of godly wisdom.

questions.question: What realization does the Preacher have about the fate of the wise and the fool?
options: Both share the same fate; death is the great equalizer
The wise are rewarded, the fool punished
The fool lives longer than the wise
questions.correctAnswer: Both share the same fate; death is the great equalizer
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:14-16 teaches that both wise and fool die and are forgotten, emphasizing the inevitability of death (Hebrews 9:27; Psalm 49:10-20; Ecclesiastes 3:19), pointing to the need for hope beyond the grave (John 11:25-26).

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2, why does the Preacher hate life and his labor under the sun?
options: Because all is vanity and vexation of spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Because all is vanity and vexation of spirit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:17-18 explains the Preacher hated life and his labor because it was grievous and vain, echoing the frustration of human toil in a fallen world (Genesis 3:17-19; Romans 8:20-22; Psalm 73:16-17).

questions.question: What concern does the Preacher express about leaving his labor to another man?
options: That the successor may be a fool and rule over his labor
That his labor will be destroyed
That others will steal his possessions
That his labor will be honored forever
questions.correctAnswer: That the successor may be a fool and rule over his labor
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:19 speaks of the uncertainty whether the one who inherits his labor will be wise or a fool, highlighting the transient nature of earthly legacy (Psalm 39:6; Job 1:21; Luke 12:20).

questions.question: What is the Preacher's attitude towards all the labor he has done under the sun?
options: He causes his heart to despair
He finds great joy and satisfaction
questions.correctAnswer: He causes his heart to despair
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:20 reveals that the Preacher's heart is caused to despair of all his labor, reflecting the futility experienced apart from God (Ecclesiastes 1:18; Psalm 73:13-16; Ecclesiastes 3:11).

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 2 say about a man who labors in wisdom, knowledge, and equity but leaves his labor to one who has not labored?
options: This is vanity and a great evil
This is the way of God's providence
This is a blessing from the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: This is vanity and a great evil
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:21 describes this situation as vanity and a great evil, underscoring the frustration of human effort without divine purpose (Psalm 49:10-15; Ecclesiastes 3:16; Job 21:7-13).

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 2, what is the ultimate gain or profit of man's labor under the sun?
questions.correctAnswer: There is no lasting profit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:22-23 state that man gains nothing lasting from all his labor and vexation, highlighting the futility of life apart from God (Psalm 39:6; Ecclesiastes 1:14; Romans 8:20-22; Matthew 6:19-21).

questions.question: What does the Preacher identify as the best thing for man to do with his labor?
options: Eat, drink, and enjoy good in his labor
questions.correctAnswer: Eat, drink, and enjoy good in his labor
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:24 teaches that the best for man is to eat, drink, and enjoy the fruits of his labor, recognizing these as gifts from God (Psalm 104:14-15; Ecclesiastes 3:13; 1 Timothy 6:17; John 6:35).

questions.question: Who does God give wisdom, knowledge, and joy to, according to Ecclesiastes 2?
options: To a man that is good in His sight
To the fool and the wise alike
questions.correctAnswer: To a man that is good in His sight
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:26 states God gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy to those who are good in His sight, reflecting God's sovereign grace (Proverbs 2:6; James 1:5; Psalm 112:1; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What does the Preacher say God gives to the sinner, as contrasted with the righteous person?
options: Travail to gather and heap up
questions.correctAnswer: Travail to gather and heap up
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 2:26 contrasts God’s gift to the sinner as travail, to gather and heap up possessions, which ultimately is vanity, echoing Proverbs 10:16; Psalm 73:3-7; Luke 12:15.
